results.abstract: Space: 1999, British television series that syndicated for 48 episodes from 1975 to 1977, will be released in new sets of videos and DVD's from A&E; photo (M)
results.snippet: ON the moon they have a problem: atomic waste shipped from earth and stored on the dark side is about to blow. ''We have magnetic energy of unprecedented violence,'' reports an officer in Moonbase Alpha, a sleekly modular outpost for 300 people on...
results.lead_paragraph: ON the moon they have a problem: atomic waste shipped from earth and stored on the dark side is about to blow. ''We have magnetic energy of unprecedented violence,'' reports an officer in Moonbase Alpha, a sleekly modular outpost for 300 people on the lunar surface. One idea is to spread the stuff out, diffusing the explosive central mass. Nice try, but futile. ''The greatest step for mankind is about to look like a stumble in the dark,'' says Commander John Koenig, portrayed with furrow-browed intensity by Martin Landau. The blast sends the Moonbase Alpha crew, smartly costumed by Rudi Gernreich, leaping and rolling around the control center. They survive to wander the universe, never to return permanently to earth. But their show -- ''Space: 1999,'' which streaked through the syndication skies for 48 episodes from 1975 to 1977 before burning up in an atmosphere more attuned to slice-of-life ''message'' shows like ''All in the Family'' -- has touched down among us in new sets of videos and DVD's from A&E.

results.abstract: Excerpts from diary kept by Bruce Wagner during his week at Sundance Film Festival, which showed his movie Women in Film; photo (M)

headline.main: Dear Diary: I've Made It to Sundance. Yes, Sundance!

results.snippet: The novelist and director Bruce Wagner's second movie, ''Women in Film,'' starring Beverly D'Angelo, Portia de Rossi and Marianne Jean-Baptiste, is a fictional portrait of three Hollywood hopefuls. It was accepted by this year's Sundance Film...
results.lead_paragraph: The novelist and director Bruce Wagner's second movie, ''Women in Film,'' starring Beverly D'Angelo, Portia de Rossi and Marianne Jean-Baptiste, is a fictional portrait of three Hollywood hopefuls. It was accepted by this year's Sundance Film Festival, which ended last Saturday. Following are excerpts from the diary Mr. Wagner kept during his week at the festival, in Park City, Utah. FRIDAY, JAN. 19 Dearest, Dearest Diary,

results.abstract: Sixteen-ton Destiny laboratory module, scientific centerpiece of International Space Station, will be lifted into space by space shuttle Atlantis on Feb 7; some scientists question cost, $1.38 billion, but NASA officials and other scientists insist that space-based research will produce valuable dividends; drawing (M)

headline.main: NASA Set to Deliver Station's Scientific Core

results.snippet: One of the most critical chapters in the young history of the International Space Station begins on Wednesday, when the space shuttle Atlantis is to lift off bearing the station's scientific centerpiece.    The 16-ton Destiny laboratory module is to...
results.lead_paragraph: One of the most critical chapters in the young history of the International Space Station begins on Wednesday, when the space shuttle Atlantis is to lift off bearing the station's scientific centerpiece. The 16-ton Destiny laboratory module is to be the focal point of more than a decade of research on the growing station.

results.abstract: Article on MaxiMog, one-of-a-kind custom expedition vehicle built by Bran Ferren and friend over past three years; high-tech off-road vehicle described; photos (M)

headline.main: A Swiss Army Knife on Wheels

results.snippet: BRAN FERREN missed the last great era of exploration by over a century. But more than a little of Sir Ernest Shackleton's adventuring spirit has found its way into the MaxiMog, a one-of-a-kind custom expedition vehicle that he and a team of dozens of...
results.lead_paragraph: BRAN FERREN missed the last great era of exploration by over a century. But more than a little of Sir Ernest Shackleton's adventuring spirit has found its way into the MaxiMog, a one-of-a-kind custom expedition vehicle that he and a team of dozens of experts built from the ground up over the last three years. He came up with the idea of a car -- he calls it the MaxiMog Global Expedition System -- that he could drive around the world while president for research and development, technology, at Walt Disney Imagineering, where he worked until last year overseeing more than 100 Imagineers, the term Disney coined for his designers 50 years ago. At Disney, Mr. Ferren was the master wizard of escapist fantasies, applying his gift for complex technologies throughout the Kingdom of the Mouse. Memorable Ferren experiences include stomach-pitching rides like the Tower of Terror's 13-story plunge and the skidding, engine-roaring Test Track developed with General Motors at Epcot Center. And now, the guru of high-tech thrills is primed for an adventure of his own. With his 12-foot high MaxiMog, Mr. Ferren, 48, stands as equipped as any explorer this side of NASA to venture into uncharted terrain. In terms of sheer brute prowess, this off-road vehicle is as macho as they come: it can pull its trailer up a 45-degree grade by engaging a high-performance drive system that powers all eight wheels. It can climb over three-foot boulders and traverse streams six feet deep; it can survey terrain for miles around by deploying a four-foot remote-controlled electric reconnaissance plane that sends back images, and whenever Mr. Ferren wants to check in with scientists or friends around the world, he can switch on a two-way video-conferencing system beamed up from the MaxiMog's own 50-foot pneumatic mast. Every contingency -- power, communications, navigation, medical support, hydraulics, climate control, safety -- has been met with state-of-the-art technology (there are heated and cooled drink holders next to the driver's seat and 1,900 lights).

results.abstract: NASA scientists attempt to link humans more closely to devices we control; goal is to utilize human gestures and muscle movements to signal control apparatus, rather than utilizing manual devices like keyboards and joysticks; drawing (M)

headline.main: Controls Rely on the Twitch of a Muscle, Not the Twitch of a Mouse

results.snippet: COMPUTERS, cell phones and other gadgets continue to shrink, but the means of interacting with them, like keyboards and keypads, are either too large and cumbersome or too small for the human hand. That is the belief of a group of NASA scientists who...
results.lead_paragraph: COMPUTERS, cell phones and other gadgets continue to shrink, but the means of interacting with them, like keyboards and keypads, are either too large and cumbersome or too small for the human hand. That is the belief of a group of NASA scientists who have been working on more direct ways to control machines, starting with jets and spacecraft. Speech recognition is one alternative, but it is not ideal for cockpits or other noisy places. So the scientists are attempting to show how gestures can link humans more directly to the devices they control. They recently demonstrated that electronic signals picked up from human muscles could be used to land a jetliner in a simulation. These kinds of controls could someday be used in things like video games as well.

results.abstract: Astronauts install Destiny science laboratory to International Space Station; photo (M)

headline.main: Astronauts Bolt Laboratory to Space Station

results.snippet: Moving with slow precision, astronauts working inside and out of the shuttle Atlantis today installed the key Destiny science laboratory to the International Space Station.    Using the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm, the astronaut Marsha S. Ivins...
results.lead_paragraph: Moving with slow precision, astronauts working inside and out of the shuttle Atlantis today installed the key Destiny science laboratory to the International Space Station. Using the shuttle's 50-foot robot arm, the astronaut Marsha S. Ivins maneuvered the massive, 29,500-pound module from the shuttle's cargo bay and inched it into its permanent position on the station.

results.abstract: Two astronauts venture outside space shuttle Atlantis on United States' 100th spacewalk, wrapping up work on International Space Station's new science laboratory; spacewalkers, Thomas D Jones and Cmdr Robert L Curbeam Jr, conduct emergency drill known as dead-guy test, for dragging incapacitated astronaut to safety; NASA estimates that 152 more spacewalks will be needed before construction of space station is completed in 2006 (M)
results.snippet: Two astronauts ventured outside the space shuttle Atlantis today on the United States' 100th spacewalk, wrapping up work on the International Space Station's new science laboratory and taking turns playing dead.    The spacewalkers, Thomas D. Jones...
results.lead_paragraph: Two astronauts ventured outside the space shuttle Atlantis today on the United States' 100th spacewalk, wrapping up work on the International Space Station's new science laboratory and taking turns playing dead. The spacewalkers, Thomas D. Jones and Cmdr. Robert L. Curbeam Jr. of the Navy, conducted an emergency drill known as the dead-guy test, for dragging an incapacitated astronaut to safety.

results.abstract: George Vecsey Sports of The Times column discusses St John's loss to Duke; describes excellent program at Duke that fosters academics as well as athletics and recruits players who will fit in with program geared to high achievement on and off court; photo (M)

headline.main: Sports of The Times; St. John's Runs Into a Pass-Fail Examination

results.snippet: WHEN they enroll in college, students do not expect seminars to be held Sunday at high noon.    Sunday noon is often not even observed by college-age people, who are indulging in that youthful activity known as sleeping in. However, thanks to the...
results.lead_paragraph: WHEN they enroll in college, students do not expect seminars to be held Sunday at high noon. Sunday noon is often not even observed by college-age people, who are indulging in that youthful activity known as sleeping in. However, thanks to the demands of television, the young players from St. John's had to endure a very public examination yesterday in Madison Square Garden.
